episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" features a variety of quirky and fascinating facts, including the evolution of human hands due to fig squeezing, the use of a ferret to clean a particle accelerator, the history of garden gnomes and their connection to John Major's family, and the accidental brilliance of scientific discoveries like a parasitic aphrodisiac in crickets.

facts.fact: There is a theory that human hands evolved as tools for assessing whether figs are soft or not.
In 1971, Fermilab used a ferret named Felicia to clean their particle accelerator tubes.
Garden gnomes were popularized by Tom Major-Ball, the father of former UK Prime Minister John Major.
The Golden Mole Award for Accidental Brilliance was set up to honor scientists who made accidental discoveries, like a parasitic aphrodisiac found in crickets.
